title: Which team will win the 2021 Formula One World Constructors' Championship?
preds: Baring a double DNF from Mercedes there's very little chance of them losing their current 28 point lead in the constructors.
Small update to reflect view that the Abu Dhabi track equally favors the two constructors' cars. Will consider making a final update after seeing Friday practice and Saturday quali.
One race left. Mercedes unlikely to fall apart.
The Perez DNF in Saudi Arabia has given Mercedes a bigger edge. I would say this outcome is a slam dunk, but after the crazy race that just finished, it's clear that anything can happen in Abu Dhabi.
Max’s encounter with the wall in the final lap of qualifying answers this question for me. Much less than 1% chance that Mercedes can screw up so badly now that RBR find a way to come back.
Saudi Arabia qualifying gives Mercedes a huge edge. Waiting to see whether Verstappen destroyed his gear-box, in which case I will increase my odds for Mercedes further.

On one hand, the margin of lead absolutely and relatively has grown since opening of question. On the other hand, Red Bull is still relatively close, having the #1 ranked driver with two races left and the last winner Hamilton. Sort of hard to believe Hamilton and other Mercedes cars will rally up a winning streak. But then again, it's close. At least in my judgement. I am not an avid fan of F1.
Mercedes seems to have the edge in engines and also so far in 2nd driver though perez seems to be improving.

Updating my forecast because I expect Hamilton to have the dominant car for the remaining two races since he managed to win Qatar with an old engine (https://www.racefans.net/2021/11/22/how-verstappen-can-win-the-formula-1-championship-at-the-next-race/). Would be even stronger for Mercedes if I weren't concerned about Bottas's reliability.

Even though RBR closed the points gap significantly today because of the BOT retirement (luck, or a sub-par 1-stop strategy call...?), the stunning engine performance of the Mercedes was on display again, confirming that Brazil was not a fluke. Overall, I think this engine performance will be decisive, as all other performance factors between RBR and Mercedes are simply too finely balanced to see a way for RBR to compensate. The remaining 15% chance of an RBR win reflects my assessment of the likelihood of another surprising racing incident in the coming races making a big impact on the Constructors' Championship.
Between two. Bookies are going with Merc. Didn't do the Maths... it seems tighter than my prediction.

Mercedes as of today 16.11.2021 is eleven points ahead of Red Bull.  The remaining races have 2 circuits where the Mercedes is seen stronger historically and have higher track potential.  Q: Chances for Red Bull to close the gap, 12 points. some info
there are 129 + 3fastest lap points to earn = 132.An average weekend a constructor like them scores 27 points, stdefv Mercedes [17-37], Red Bull [15-39]
there is never been this season a 1-2 for the same constructors Mercedes or Red Bull. ways and chances for Red Bull to close >11 points both teams in top5, Red Bull better positioned
7 out of 19 races so far Mercedes and Red Bull occupied 4 out of first 5 positions, 40% that this happens again in next 3 races and in such instances, there is 50% chance that Red Bull takes the most points, bot from those only 70% where the delta is 10 points. 
<15% chance that Red Bull can close >11points this way once Red Bull doing 1-3 or 1-2 
note: so far this season we have not seen any 1-2 in any race
Mercedes have had 6/19 races their two drivers in top 3.
Red Bull have had 4/19 races their two drivers in top 3. 
Chances that Red Bull has this happen one time more than Mercedes in next 3 races is unlikely
5% chances that Red Bull can close >11points gap this way Mercedes not in top 10
6/19 races Red bull had a driver not ending in top 10
7/19 races Mercedes gad a driver not ending in top 10
chance that this happens in next 3 races is 2/3 but the chance that it happens both to Mercedes is <10%.  Form curve and race tracks upcoming has favour for Mercedes
<10% chance that Red Bull closes about 11 points or more this way SUMMARY There is high chance that Red Bull will close in one of the 3 remaining races the gap with 11 points or more in a weekend, but equally or higher chance that Mercedes will do the same in another and undo the gap. there is remote chance that Red Bull has each of 3 weekends 4 points more than Mercedes Outlier chances for mechanical breakdown or collision, differential is higher for Mercedes esp with Bottas. overarching chance for Red Bull to win <20%

Mercedes (currently ahead) winning the constructors championship seems more likely as Lewis attempts to close the gap between himself and Max. I also feel that Bottas (on the podium 10 times in 19 races) is likely to finish ahead of Perez (5 podiums).
Updated to reflect Sao Paulo GP results

Updating to reflect Brazil GP outcomes, with key implication being that Mercedes now probably have the slightly (but meaningfully!) faster racecar over a race distance, and have expanded their Championship points lead. You can infer from the magnitude of my forecast change how surprised I am by this development!

Bookies and crowd (less so) favour Red Bull. I am struggling to get head round this, especially now it's likely that RB not going to outscore Merc by a great deal in Brazil.
Last 3 tracks look good for Merc and Verstappen doesn't give a hoot about constructors deep down (2nds could be enough).

Updating after the Brazil sprint race, where Mercedes actually gained another point on Red Bull. The Red Bulls looked surprisingly weak, with Bottas holding off Verstappen and Sainz holding off Perez. Meanwhile, Hamilton confirmed my guess that he would be highly motivated and effective after taking a new ICE. His 10th-place starting position for Brazil is the best Mercedes could have hoped for. Game on!

Verstappen v. Hamilton will most likely be very close. Bottas’ missing points in the coming races will most likely decide this. Checo’s results keep improving, so I assess this to be Red Bull’s championship to lose, not Mercedes’. Mercedes’ new engines are probably a red herring, it’s the relative performance of the #2 drivers that will most likely be decisive. In all cases it’s probably going to be very close at the end.

It couldn't be closer. But Mercedes has the tiniest of edges and Hamilton is on pole for the sprint race in Brazil. I'm giving Bottas the slightest of edges over Perez for the remaining four races and expecting Hamilton to make a valiant (if likely unsuccessful) effort to overtake Verstappen for the driver's championship, all of which would add up to a Mercedes constructors championship.
